description:
Aestuariimicrobium soli is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria. It was first isolated from soil samples collected from an estuarine environment.

The cells of Aestuariimicrobium soli are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and rod-shaped. They are typically 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.0-2.0 μm in length.

This bacterium is considered aerobic, meaning it requires oxygen for growth and metabolism. It is also chemoheterotrophic, which indicates that it uses organic compounds as both its carbon and energy sources.

Aestuariimicrobium soli is capable of growing at a wide range of temperatures, from 10°C to 40°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. It can tolerate moderate levels of salinity, making it well-suited for the estuarine environment from which it was isolated.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that Aestuariimicrobium soli is most closely related to other bacterial species within the genus Aestuariimicrobium, which are also commonly found in estuarine and coastal habitats.

The ecological role and specific metabolic capabilities of Aestuariimicrobium soli in its natural environment are still under investigation, as further research is needed to understand its importance and potential applications.
